1.brief: to descend (literally, to go downwards; or conventionally to a lower region, as the shore, a boundary, the enemy, etc.; or figuratively, to fall); causatively, to bring down (in all the above applications)
Timnah, the name of two places in Palestine
to see, literally or figuratively (in numerous applications, direct and implied, transitive, intransitive and causative)
Timnah, the name of two places in Palestine
a daughter (used in the same wide sense as other terms of relationship, literally and figuratively)
a Pelishtite or inhabitant of Pelesheth

2.brief: to ascend, intransitively (be high) or actively (mount); used in a great variety of senses, primary and secondary, literal and figurative

properly, to front, i.e. stand boldly out opposite; by implication (causatively), to manifest; figuratively, to announce (always by word of mouth to one present); specifically, to expose, predict, explain, praise
father, in a literal and immediate, or figurative and remote application
a mother (as the bond of the family); in a wide sense (both literally and figuratively (like father))
to see, literally or figuratively (in numerous applications, direct and implied, transitive, intransitive and causative)
Timnah, the name of two places in Palestine

properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)
